summary: The U.S. District Court for the Western District of Oklahoma on February 7, 2020, entered a final judgment against Oklahoma Attorney General Jeff Sessions and two of his former supervisors for violating the antifraud provisions of Section 10(b) of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 ("Exchange Act") and Rule 10b-5 thereunder.  The SEC's complaint, filed in federal court in Oklahoma City, Oklahoma, alleges that the CCRWD was not entitled to immunity under the federal securities laws because it was not an arm of the State of Oklahoma.  According to the SEC's order, filed on May 19, 2019, the Court found that, contrary to the representations in the complaint, the defendants were entitled to qualified immunity because they were not state-affiliated and did not have the authority to issue bonds or levy taxes on their own behalf.  In addition, the court found that the defendants had no "authority to levy any taxes whatsoever or make any assessments on property, real or personal," and neither did they have the right to impose any civil penalties.  Without admitting or denying the allegations, the Defendants consented to the entry of final judgments that permanently restrains and enjoin them from violating the above-mentioned provisions of the securities laws, order them to pay disgorgement, prejudgment interest, and a civil penalty equal to the amount of their profits, and impose a $25,000 civil penalty against each of the defendants.  On February 20, 2020 the court granted the SEC a temporary restraining order and ordered the defendants to return their allegedly ill-gotten gains plus interest, pay civil penalties, and provide for an officer and director bar.  A hearing on February 21, 2020 is scheduled for 7:30 p.m. The SEC appreciates the assistance of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, the Oklahoma Secretary of State's Office, and the Oklahoma Department of Health and Human Services.
